cells.data:
Propositional functions (some with multiple variables)

Universal quantifications

$P(x)$ is a propositional function of $x$

By $\forall x : P(x)$ we mean $P(x)$ holds for all $x$ in the domain
To prove it false, you need one counter example. To prove it true, you must show that it holds for all values of $x$ in the domain 
That is, $\forall x : P(x) \equiv P(x_1) \land \dots \land P(x_n)$

By $\exists x : P(x)$ we mean there exists at least one $x$ in the domain such that $P(x)$ holds 
To prove it true, you need one example. To prove it false, you must show that there is no such value of $x$ in the domain
That is, $\exists x : P(x) \equiv P(x_1) \lor \dots \lor P(x_n)$

By $\exists! x : P(x)$ we mean there exists a unique $x$ such that $P(x)$ holds

Logical equivalence involving quantifiers

$\neg (\forall x : P(x)) \equiv \exists x : \neg P(x)$

Same truth values no matter the predicates or domains

Proofs:
1. Argue that if LHS is T than RHS is T
2. Argue that if RHS is T than LHS is T

$\neg (\exists x : P(x)) \equiv \forall x : \neg P(x)$

Not logically equivalent if one can be false while the other is true

$\exists$ a student $s \in$ this class : $s$ has visited Japan
alternately,
Let $C$ = this class, $P(s)$ : $s$ has visited Japan
$\exists s \in C : P(s)$
